sentence.Network_cn: 肉块应该用文火烹煮，以免烧过了头。

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English: from Old French excessif, -ive, from medieval Latin excessivus, from Latin excedere 'surpass' (see exceed)

entry.def: If you describe the amount or level of something as excessive, you disapprove of it because it is more or higher than is necessary or reasonable.

example.ex: ...the alleged use of excessive force by police...
The government says that local authority spending is excessive.
example.tran: 政府称地方当局开支过大。

sentences.sentence: "his dress stops just short of undue elegance"

excess[n.过度,过剩]+ive……的→adj.过分的;过度的
in不+accessible[adj.能接近的;可进去的]→adj.难以接近的
suc随后+cess行走,前进+ive……的→随后跟上→连续的
access接近+ory表形容词或名词→接近的物→附加物,附属的

con共同+cess后退+ion动作或状态→n.让步;退位
ne=need需要+cess行走,前进+ary物→n.必需品

re回+cess行走,前进→走回去→休息

Sentence.sentence: Only years later did we understand the trade-offs this involved: the creation of excessive bureaucracies(官僚机构),the difficulty of forging personal connections between teachers and students.
Concern about excessive Internet use isn't new.

But as reliance on the Web grows, there are signs that the question is getting more serious attention: Last month, a study published in CNS Spectrums claimed to be the first large-scale look at excessive Internet use

L) The college admission essay contains the grandest American themes―status anxiety, parental piety (孝顺), intellectual standards—and so it is only a matter of time before it becomes infected by the country's culture of excessive concern with self-esteem.
Rule against Monsanto's excessive extension of its patent rights

Of the produce that does appear in the supermarket, commonly used sales promotions frequently encourage customers to purchase excessive quantities which, in the case of perishable foodstuffs, inevitably generate wastage in the home.

means.word_mean: 过度的, 过分的; 极度的

The prices at this hotel are excessive.
